snippet.textDisplay:
While the intent here is to give a lesson on exponential and logistic growth as general phenomena, with epidemics as a timely case study, there are a few notes worth adding when it comes to epidemics themselves. Probably the most important, mentioned only as a small on-screen note, is that these models should account for the amount of time someone with the virus remains infectious. Those who recover (or die) are no longer able to spread it, and so don't factor into the growth equation. The faster the growth, the less this matters, since at each point on the curve most people with the virus will have only contracted it recently, but especially in the long run or with slower growth, any realistic model has to consider this. The other factor, which I was hesitant to even get into here, is the extent to which reported cases reflect real cases.

Generalizing away from epidemics, though, the key upshot is to be aware of phenomena where the rate of growth is proportional to the size of the thing growing. Compound interest, technological progress, population growth, and many other things fit this pattern, and it's shocking how bad our intuitions can be at recognizing what it means.
snippet.textOriginal:
While the intent here is to give a lesson on exponential and logistic growth as general phenomena, with epidemics as a timely case study, there are a few notes worth adding when it comes to epidemics themselves.  Probably the most important, mentioned only as a small on-screen note, is that these models should account for the amount of time someone with the virus remains infectious.  Those who recover (or die) are no longer able to spread it, and so don't factor into the growth equation.  The faster the growth, the less this matters, since at each point on the curve most people with the virus will have only contracted it recently, but especially in the long run or with slower growth, any realistic model has to consider this.  The other factor, which I was hesitant to even get into here, is the extent to which reported cases reflect real cases.

Generalizing away from epidemics, though, the key upshot is to be aware of phenomena where the rate of growth is proportional to the size of the thing growing.  Compound interest, technological progress, population growth, and many other things fit this pattern, and it's shocking how bad our intuitions can be at recognizing what it means.

snippet.textDisplay:
A problem with the statistics side of epidemics, is that you allways have to keep in mind that numbers are NEVER 100% accurate, and that alot of contries are testing at different rates/magnetudes, in the example, south korea has an innsane number compared to manny other contries, but it is allso one of the most agressive when it comes to testing and fighting the spread. Manny other contries are doing a lesser effort into quantifying their testing, and in some cases allmost not quantifying the virus at all. This is the problem of only using hard numbers, since you have to allways have unknown variables that you only can guess the magnitude at compared to other patterns.
It is allso why the "spanish flue" is named spanish flue, and not asian flue where the genom originated, spain recorded and vent against it agressivly and hadd the most accurate numbers, while other places where more devestated/infected, spain just hadd a more agressive and accurate number earligher in the pandemic.
Edit: ofc you can get close to accurate numbers with more information and integrate it per contry basis and so on, but it was just to point out that hard numbers are NEVER 100% accurate in practical application, ESPECIALY when human interferance is involved, we are verry unlogical and unpredictable creatures (ofc there is a predictability of masses, 1 individual can be a superspreader and so forth). anny number that is applied to humans are by nature not 100% accurate since we do not have 100% hard data on evry human being on the planet.

snippet.textDisplay: I have first hand accounts of how in the italian region of Tuscany, regional administration is actively pressuring the epidemiology task-force that is studing the data into declaring that we are close to the inflection point (or that it will come soon), while epidemiologists themselves are saying it's too early and that the data only tells us so much. They are also attempting to match the fittings from chinese regions to Tuscany (and other italian regions as well) in an attempt to minimize the issue or prove that the trend will be the same, while there are so many different factors at play that clearly make the italian outbreak different from the chinese one (including the way containment measures were applied, which definitely influences the number E). Also, they initially refused to test all suspect cases who self-reported to hospitals (after the scare they started testing way more pervasively) and actively maintained an attitude aimed at trying to conceal numbers. SMH I really can't understand how giving fake numbers can have any positive impact on the future of the epidemy

World Pop : 7,635,452,000
Recovered : 62,692

CFR : 3.48% to 5.85%

snippet.textDisplay:
Highly relevant to current events. Great job, Grant.

Side note for wanna-be data scientists: using R-square on time-series data is dubious since R-square tends to inflate with autocorrelated data (e.g., temporal, spatial, and spatio-temporal data). As a rule of thumb, use of R-square should be avoided with time-series data.
snippet.textOriginal:
Highly relevant to current events.  Great job, Grant.

Side note for wanna-be data scientists: using R-square on time-series data is dubious since R-square tends to inflate with autocorrelated data (e.g., temporal, spatial, and spatio-temporal data).  As a rule of thumb, use of R-square should be avoided with time-series data.

snippet.textDisplay:
3:07 Oh, so considering that the UK is one month behind South Korea, South Korea is doing horribly better than the UK, as the UK is likely to get 1M cases in a month, while South Korea has only 6,593 cases given that they got this hit earlier.

Another point about 3:00 6,593 vs. 64 cases, South Korea has conducted more than 10,000 (recently even about 20,000) tests a day, while we don't know how many tests the UK actually conducted. So this comparison might not be fair. You can imagine some countries that do not conduct any test at all and found zero cases.
snippet.textOriginal:
3:07 Oh, so considering that the UK is one month behind South Korea, South Korea is doing horribly better than the UK, as the UK is likely to get 1M cases in a month, while South Korea has only 6,593 cases given that they got this hit earlier.

Another point about 3:00 6,593 vs. 64 cases, South Korea has conducted more than 10,000 (recently even about 20,000) tests a day, while we don't know how many tests the UK actually conducted. So this comparison might not be fair. You can imagine some countries that do not conduct any test at all and found zero cases.

snippet.textDisplay:
I am noticing that at no time does he discuss that the death rate is pretty small even though it's higher than the normal flu. Because it only seems to be affecting older people, with underlying, aggravating health conditions that exacerbate the issue. Younger people are frequently, at least as they see it, catching the virus not even noticing they had the flu. That's the unusual thing with this particular strain of the Coronavirus.

It appears that a high number of people are getting the Ovid 19 Coronavirus and getting over it without ever being reported. Which would remove them from being a transmitting agent to someone who is nearly immune. They can't transmit it as the virus cannot become symptomatic in their system.

Thanks for the math brush up. you should always be wary, the problem is is too many people are overreacting.

snippet.textDisplay: I teach almost this exact same subject (logistical growth) as an application in Managerial Economics.  The Inflection Point, i.e. the "point of diminishing return" is a concept that some have much difficulty understanding.
snippet.textOriginal: I teach almost this exact same subject (logistical growth) as an application in Managerial Economics.  The Inflection Point, i.e. the "point of diminishing return" is a concept that some have much difficulty understanding.

snippet.textDisplay:
The cause is basically that outside of China, negligence and carelessness is the norm when it comes to fighting the virus.
In the Netherlands right now, those confirmed infected are only in quarantine voluntarily (they can break it at any time without consequences) and those in contact with confirmed cases are not quarantined at all and are free to travel and go to work or schools to infect more people. The authorities even told bold-faced lies speaking of a 'non-infectious period' while we've known for months that Covid-19 can be transmitted asymptomatically. 900 fraternity arseholes went skiiing right in the North-Italian hot zone a few days ago, and were allowed to come back, not being quarantined at all.


As a result the number of cases has exploded from 2 to 250+ within one week. Of 91 patients they haven't got a clue how they got infected. We've lost control.


Likewise Italy didn't do anything until it was way too late.


Meanwhile, this weekend Hong Kong news reported the only two new cases in Hong Kong were both infected in Europe. There are no new domestic cases there due to effective measures being taken.
snippet.textOriginal:
The cause is basically that outside of China, negligence and carelessness is the norm when it comes to fighting the virus.
In the Netherlands right now, those confirmed infected are only in quarantine voluntarily (they can break it at any time without consequences) and those in contact with confirmed cases are not quarantined at all and are free to travel and go to work or schools to infect more people. The authorities even told bold-faced lies speaking of a 'non-infectious period' while we've known for months that Covid-19 can be transmitted asymptomatically. 900 fraternity arseholes went skiiing right in the North-Italian hot zone a few days ago, and were allowed to come back, not being quarantined at all.


As a result the number of cases has exploded from 2 to 250+ within one week. Of 91 patients they haven't got a clue how they got infected. We've lost control.


Likewise Italy didn't do anything until it was way too late.


Meanwhile, this weekend Hong Kong news reported the only two new cases in Hong Kong were both infected in Europe. There are no new domestic cases there due to effective measures being taken.
